729398f-a.title: Richmond: Richmond Road - New Dorp Lane
729398f-a.text:
Richmond Road, north side, adjoining (to the east) New Dorp
Lane, showing the Patten House. It was built in 1836 by Colonel
John Patten as a hostelry to accommodatethe crowds who came to
see the New Dorp races. It was the neadquarters of General Van
Buren, commanding the State Militia of this military district.
Commodore Vanderbilt was a frequent visitor here. It was also the
headquarters of the Owls Club of which Wm. H. Vanderbilt, Senator
''Sam'' Frost and Judge Daniel Clawson were members. It closed as a
public hostelry in 1887, after which it was used by Father MoGlynn
as a branch of a Roman Catholic institution. Later it was used as
a tenement house by Italian ragpickers. It was condemned by the
Board of Wealth as a hazard to health and safety and was finally
razed in 1902. See the ''New York Tribune, June 29, 1902, illus-
trated sup3lenent, p. S.
About 1900
By Eugene G. Putnam
From Staten Island Museum Collection through P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS
